title: 106_hr3292
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cat Island National Wildlife Refuge Establishment Act". Cat Island, Louisiana, is the southernmost unleveed portion of the Mississippi River and supports a high density of virgin bald cypress trees, including the Nation's champion cypress tree. It is important habitat for declining species of forest songbirds, wintering waterfowl, deer, turkey, and furbearers. Conservation efforts through inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System would benefit the area's habitat. The Cat Island area in Louisiana, with its virgin bald cypress trees and diverse wildlife, is deserving of inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System to meet habitat conservation goals and provide valuable recreational opportunities. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Refuge" refers to the Cat Island National Wildlife Refuge, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. PURPOSES. The Cat Island National Wildlife Refuge is established to conserve habitats for migratory birds, manage aquatic resources, preserve native bottomland communities, aid in the recovery of endangered species, and promote volunteer involvement. The Cat Island National Wildlife Refuge aims to conserve habitats for migratory birds, manage aquatic resources, preserve native bottomland communities, aid in the recovery of endangered species, and promote volunteer involvement through partnerships with various organizations and public awareness initiatives. Establishment of refuge. The Secretary is authorized to establish the Cat Island National Wildlife Refuge, consisting of approximately 36,500 acres of land and water. Minor boundary revisions may be made to facilitate property acquisition. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands and waters within the designated boundary. The Refuge will be established by publication in the Federal Register. The Secretary is authorized to establish the Cat Island National Wildlife Refuge, consisting of approximately 36,500 acres of land and water. Minor boundary revisions may be made to facilitate property acquisition. Lands and waters within the designated boundary can be acquired for the Refuge, with publication in the Federal Register and local circulation when sufficient property is acquired. The Secretary will administer lands and waters acquired under this Act in accordance with the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act. Priority uses for the Refuge include hunting, fishing, wildlife observation, photography, and environmental education. Authorization of appropriations for the Department of the Interior for land acquisition and Refuge development. Designation of the Herbert H. Bateman Education and Administrative Center within Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge. Technical corrections. Section 6 of the Junior Duck Stamp Conservation and Design Program Act of 1994 is redesignated as section 7. Section 6 of the Cahaba River National Wildlife Refuge Establishment Act is amended to update references to the Endangered Species Act and the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act. The Red River National Wildlife Refuge Act of 1966 is amended to update references to specific paragraphs in the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
